title: Basic Structure Doctrine in Indian Constitution

information.title: Definition
information.description: The Basic Structure Doctrine is a judicial principle that the Constitution of India has certain basic features that cannot be altered or destroyed through amendments by the parliament. It was evolved by the Supreme Court of India in the landmark case of Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala (1973).

information.title: Origin
information.description: The doctrine emerged as a response to the government's attempts to amend the Constitution in ways that could potentially undermine its core principles. It was first outlined in the Kesavananda Bharati case, where a 13-judge bench ruled by a 7-6 majority.

information.title: Key Features
information.description: While the Supreme Court has not provided an exhaustive list, some of the basic features identified include: supremacy of the Constitution, republican and democratic form of government, secular character of the Constitution, separation of powers, and federalism.

information.title: Significance
information.description: The doctrine acts as a check on the power of the Parliament to amend the Constitution. It ensures that the fundamental nature of the Indian Constitution cannot be altered to fit the whims of a particular government or a temporary majority.

information.title: Application
information.description: The doctrine has been applied in several subsequent cases. For instance, in the Minerva Mills case (1980), the Supreme Court used this doctrine to strike down clauses of the 42nd Amendment which had given the Parliament unlimited power to amend the Constitution.

information.title: Criticism
information.description: The doctrine has been criticized by some as being undemocratic, arguing that it gives too much power to unelected judges to determine what constitutes the 'basic structure'. However, supporters argue it's necessary to protect the essence of the Constitution.

quizQuestions.question: In which case was the Basic Structure Doctrine first outlined?
options: Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala
Golak Nath v. State of Punjab
Minerva Mills v. Union of India
quizQuestions.correctAnswer: Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala

quizQuestions.question: What is the main purpose of the Basic Structure Doctrine?
options: To protect certain fundamental features of the Constitution from being amended
To give unlimited power to Parliament to amend the Constitution
To abolish the power of judicial review
To change the federal structure to unitary
quizQuestions.correctAnswer: To protect certain fundamental features of the Constitution from being amended
